title: 115_hr3342
content: The "Sanctioning the Use of Civilians as Defenseless Shields Act" condemns the use of innocent civilians as human shields and imposes sanctions on foreign persons responsible for this act. The President is required to impose mandatory sanctions and may impose permissive sanctions on individuals listed. The President must annually submit a list to Congress of foreign persons involved with Hizballah or Hamas who use civilians as shields to protect military targets. The President must annually submit a list to Congress of foreign persons who support or engage in acts involving Hizballah or Hamas using civilians to shield military objectives from attack. The President must submit an annual list to Congress of foreign persons supporting or engaging in acts involving Hizballah or Hamas using civilians to shield military objectives from attack. Sanctions imposed on such individuals or entities include blocking and prohibiting transactions involving their property in the United States. Aliens subject to sanctions under subsection (a) are ineligible for visas, admission, or parole into the United States. Any current visas issued to such aliens will be revoked. Aliens subject to sanctions under subsection (a) are ineligible for visas, admission, or parole into the United States, and any current visas issued to them will be revoked. Exceptions may apply for individuals necessary to comply with international obligations. Penalties under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act apply to those knowingly violating these sanctions. (f) Procedures for Judicial Review of Classified Information.-- If a finding under this section is based on classified information, the President may submit such information to the court ex parte and in camera. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to contradict existing laws regarding classified information. The President has the authority to waive sanctions under this section if it is in the national security interest. The President can also use regulatory authority under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to implement this section. Regulations must be prescribed within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, terms like "admitted," "alien," and "agency or instrumentality of a foreign state" are defined according to specific sections of relevant laws. In this section, "agency or instrumentality of a foreign state" is defined as per section 1603(b) of title 28, US Code. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. A "foreign person" includes citizens or entities not solely under US laws. The term "Hamas" is also defined. The term "Hamas" refers to the entity designated as a foreign terrorist organization by the Secretary of State or any person identified as an agent of Hamas on the list of specially designated nationals. The term "Hizballah" similarly refers to the entity designated as a foreign terrorist organization by the Secretary of State. Section 5 of the Act states that it will expire on December 31, 2023.
